channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Tropical-forest destruction has slowed — but is still too high
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00989-7

Ten football pitches’ worth of forest were lost per minute in 2023, suggesting that countries are not doing enough to halt deforestation.
item.dc:title: Tropical-forest destruction has slowed — but is still too high
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: Pregnancy’s effect on ‘biological’ age, polite birds, and the carbon cost of home-grown veg
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00990-0

We round up some recent stories from the Nature Briefing.
item.dc:title: Pregnancy’s effect on ‘biological’ age, polite birds, and the carbon cost of home-grown veg
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Noah Baker
Flora Graham

item.title: Fossils document evolutionary changes of jaw joint to mammalian middle ear
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07235-0

A new morganucodontan-like species from the Jurassic in China shows evidence of a loss of load-bearing function in the articular–quadrate jaw joint, which probably had a role in the evolution of the mammalian middle ear.
item.dc:title: Fossils document evolutionary changes of jaw joint to mammalian middle ear
item.dc:creator: Fangyuan Mao
Chi Zhang
Jicheng Ren
Tao Wang
Guofu Wang
Fakui Zhang
Thomas Rich
Patricia Vickers-Rich
Jin Meng

item.title: Mechanical activation opens a lipid-lined pore in OSCA ion channels
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07256-9

The molecular basis of OSCA/TMEM63 channel mechanosensitivity was investigated by determining 44 cryogenic electron microscopy structures of channels in different environments, expanding understanding of channel-mediated mechanotransduction and pore formation, with implications for two protein families.
item.dc:title: Mechanical activation opens a lipid-lined pore in OSCA ion channels
item.dc:creator: Yaoyao Han
Zijing Zhou
Ruitao Jin
Fei Dai
Yifan Ge

item.title: Phase-change memory via a phase-changeable self-confined nano-filament
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07230-5

We present a device that can reduce the phase-change memory reset current while maintaining a high on/off ratio, fast speed and small variations, representing advances for neuromorphic computing systems.
item.dc:title: Phase-change memory via a phase-changeable self-confined nano-filament
item.dc:creator: See-On Park
Seokman Hong
Su-Jin Sung
Dawon Kim
Seokho Seo
Hakcheon Jeong
Taehoon Park
Won Joon Cho
Jeehwan Kim
Shinhyun Choi

item.title: Improving prime editing with an endogenous small RNA-binding protein
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07259-6

Genome-scale genetic screens identify the small RNA-binding protein La as a strong mediator of prime editing.
item.dc:title: Improving prime editing with an endogenous small RNA-binding protein
item.dc:creator: Jun Yan
Paul Oyler-Castrillo
Purnima Ravisankar

item.title: The variation and evolution of complete human centromeres
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07278-3

A comparison of two complete sets of human centromeres reveals that the centromeres show at least a 4.1-fold increase in single-nucleotide variation compared with their unique flanks, and up to 3-fold variation in size, resulting from an accelerated mutation rate.
item.dc:title: The variation and evolution of complete human centromeres
item.dc:creator: Glennis A. Logsdon
Allison N. Rozanski
Fedor Ryabov

item.title: Bridging structural and cell biology with cryo-electron microscopy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07198-2

The interplay between cryo-electron microscopy and cryo-electron tomography to define complex macromolecular assemblies and visualize them in situ is explored.
item.dc:title: Bridging structural and cell biology with cryo-electron microscopy
item.dc:creator: Eva Nogales
Julia Mahamid

item.title: Interim analyses of a first-in-human phase 1/2 mRNA trial for propionic acidaemia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07266-7

Interim data from a clinical trial of mRNA-3927—an mRNA therapeutic for propionic acidaemia—provide early indications of the safety and efficacy of the treatment, and suggest that this approach might be applicable to other rare diseases.
item.dc:title: Interim analyses of a first-in-human phase 1/2 mRNA trial for propionic acidaemia
item.dc:creator: Dwight Koeberl
Andreas Schulze

Vanja Sikirica

Min Liang

Stephanie Grunewald

item.title: Heat flows enrich prebiotic building blocks and enhance their reactivity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07193-7

Heat flows through thin, crack-like geo-compartments are shown to purify previously mixed compounds and enhance their reactivity, providing a selective mechanism for separating molecules relevant to the chemical origins of life.
item.dc:title: Heat flows enrich prebiotic building blocks and enhance their reactivity
item.dc:creator: Thomas Matreux
Paula Aikkila
Bettina Scheu
Dieter Braun
Christof B. Mast

item.title: Structural basis of Integrator-dependent RNA polymerase II termination
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07269-4

Cryo-electron microscopy structures of the human Integrator complex in three different functional states shed light on how Integrator terminates RNA polymerase II (Pol II) transcription by disengaging Pol II from the DNA template.
item.dc:title: Structural basis of Integrator-dependent RNA polymerase II termination
item.dc:creator: Isaac Fianu
Moritz Ochmann
James L. Walshe
Olexandr Dybkov
Joseph Neos Cruz
Henning Urlaub
Patrick Cramer

item.title: A brain-specific angiogenic mechanism enabled by tip cell specialization
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07283-6

A molecular mechanism for brain-specific angiogenesis operates under the control of Wnt7a/b ligands.
item.dc:title: A brain-specific angiogenic mechanism enabled by tip cell specialization
item.dc:creator: Giel Schevenels
Pauline Cabochette

item.title: An optical tweezer array of ultracold polyatomic molecules
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07199-1

An optical tweezer array of individual polyatomic molecules is created, revealing the obvious state control in the tweezer array and enabling further research on polyatomic molecules with diverse spatial arrangements.
item.dc:title: An optical tweezer array of ultracold polyatomic molecules
item.dc:creator: Nathaniel B. Vilas
Paige Robichaud
Christian Hallas
Grace K. Li
Loïc Anderegg
John M. Doyle

item.title: Molecular insights into capsular polysaccharide secretion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07248-9

An ensemble of cryo-electron microscopy structures of the KpsMT ABC transporter in complex with the KpsE co-polymerase and a glycolipid substrate reveal how capsular polysaccharides are recognized and translocated across bacterial cell membranes.
item.dc:title: Molecular insights into capsular polysaccharide secretion
item.dc:creator: Jeremi Kuklewicz
Jochen Zimmer

item.title: Shell buckling for programmable metafluids
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07163-z

A metafluid with programmable compressibility, optical behaviour and viscosity is realized by mixing deformable spherical shells that undergo buckling within an incompressible fluid; the versatility of these metafluids opens up numerous opportunities for functionality.
item.dc:title: Shell buckling for programmable metafluids
item.dc:creator: Adel Djellouli
Bert Van Raemdonck
Yang Wang
Yi Yang
Anthony Caillaud
David Weitz
Shmuel Rubinstein
Benjamin Gorissen
Katia Bertoldi

item.title: Jurassic shuotheriids show earliest dental diversification of mammaliaforms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07258-7

A newly described fossil mammaliaform from the Jurassic period of China shows that the shuotheriids are allied to the docodonts, and provides details on the processes of tooth evolution in early mammals.
item.dc:title: Jurassic shuotheriids show earliest dental diversification of mammaliaforms
item.dc:creator: Fangyuan Mao
Zhiyu Li
Zhili Wang
Chi Zhang
Thomas Rich
Patricia Vickers-Rich
Jin Meng

item.title: Ancestral allele of DNA polymerase gamma modifies antiviral tolerance
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07260-z

The POLG1 mutation p.W748S, which is associated with mitochondrial recessive ataxia syndrome, dampens innate immune responses by compromising mtDNA replisome stability, and this explains why a viral infection can trigger the development of the disease and contribute to its variable clinical manifestation.
item.dc:title: Ancestral allele of DNA polymerase gamma modifies antiviral tolerance
item.dc:creator: Yilin Kang
Jussi Hepojoki
Rocio Sartori Maldonado
Takayuki Mito

item.title: Immune microniches shape intestinal T<sub>reg</sub> function
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07251-0

Studies in mice show that effector T regulatory cells in the gut are most functional in the lamina propria, but this homeostatic niche is disrupted in inflammation, suggesting a spatial mechanism of tolerance to commensal microorganisms.
item.dc:title: Immune microniches shape intestinal T<sub>reg</sub> function
item.dc:creator: Yisu Gu
Raquel Bartolomé-Casado
Chuan Xu
Alice Bertocchi

Fiona Powrie

item.title: Metal telluride nanosheets by scalable solid lithiation and exfoliation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07209-2

Fast and scalable synthesis of a variety of transition metal telluride nanosheets by solid lithiation and hydrolysis is demonstrated and several interesting quantum phenomena were observed, such as quantum oscillations and giant magnetoresistance.
item.dc:title: Metal telluride nanosheets by scalable solid lithiation and exfoliation
item.dc:creator: Liangzhu Zhang

item.title: Artificial intelligence can provide accurate forecasts of extreme floods at global scale
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00835-w

Anthropogenic climate change is accelerating the hydrological cycle, causing an increase in the risk of flood-related disasters. A system that uses artificial intelligence allows the creation of reliable, global river flood forecasts, even in places where accurate local data are not available.
item.dc:title: Artificial intelligence can provide accurate forecasts of extreme floods at global scale

item.title: A quirky fluid that has robotic capabilities
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00888-x

Scientists have designed a liquid that behaves as both a solid and a fluid owing to the presence of tiny gas-filled capsules. An unusual relationship between pressure and volume enables this material to grasp fragile objects.
item.dc:title: A quirky fluid that has robotic capabilities
item.dc:creator: P.-T. Brun

item.title: mRNA drug offers hope for treating a devastating childhood disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00954-4

Drug trial results show that vaccines aren’t the only use for the mRNA technology behind the most widely used COVID-19 jabs.
item.dc:title: mRNA drug offers hope for treating a devastating childhood disease
item.dc:creator: Elie Dolgin

item.title: Total solar eclipse 2024: how it will help scientists to study the Sun
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00973-1

The Sun’s mysterious outer atmosphere, the corona, will become easier to view from Earth on 8 April.
item.dc:title: Total solar eclipse 2024: how it will help scientists to study the Sun
item.dc:creator: Sumeet Kulkarni

item.title: Time to sound the alarm about the hidden epidemic of kidney disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00961-5

With rates rising around the world, public-health leaders must prioritize prevention, treatment, funding and data.
item.dc:title: Time to sound the alarm about the hidden epidemic of kidney disease

item.title: Five steps to connect genetic risk variants to disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00061-4

Genetic variants contribute to the risk of developing certain diseases, but identifying the genes and molecular pathways under their control has been difficult. Now, a systematic approach to pinpointing these factors yields insights into how a specific pathway in endothelial cells influences the risk of coronary artery disease.
item.dc:title: Five steps to connect genetic risk variants to disease

item.title: Trio of radicals choreographed for versatile chemical reaction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00735-z

The idea that three different free radicals could be used together to carry out specific steps in a chemical reaction has long been implausible. A ‘radical sorting’ strategy now achieves this feat to make organic molecules.
item.dc:title: Trio of radicals choreographed for versatile chemical reaction
item.dc:creator: Kenneth F. Clark
John A. Murphy

item.title: Why loneliness is bad for your health
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00900-4

A lack of social interaction is linked to a higher risk of cardiovascular disease, dementia and more. Researchers are unpicking how the brain mediates these effects.
item.dc:title: Why loneliness is bad for your health
item.dc:creator: Saima May Sidik

item.title: These monkeys make no sense
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00898-9

Following the evidence.
item.dc:title: These monkeys make no sense
item.dc:creator: Shahar Dubiner

item.title: Diabetes drug slows development of Parkinson’s disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00974-0

The drug, which is in the same family as blockbuster weight-loss drugs such as Wegovy, slowed development of symptoms by a small but statistically significant amount.
item.dc:title: Diabetes drug slows development of Parkinson’s disease
item.dc:creator: David Adam

item.title: Taiwan hit by biggest earthquake in 25 years: why scientists weren’t surprised
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00988-8

A complex network of faults lies in the area that experienced Taiwan’s earthquake, with scientists warning to expect more shocks.
item.dc:title: Taiwan hit by biggest earthquake in 25 years: why scientists weren’t surprised
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: The EU’s ominous emphasis on ‘open strategic autonomy’ in research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00962-4

A reboot of the flagship Horizon Europe fund risks prioritizing a mindset geared towards security over open, future-facing research collaboration.
item.dc:title: The EU’s ominous emphasis on ‘open strategic autonomy’ in research

item.title: Author Correction: SARS-CoV-2 neutralizing antibody structures inform therapeutic strategies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07344-w

Author Correction: SARS-CoV-2 neutralizing antibody structures inform therapeutic strategies
item.dc:title: Author Correction: SARS-CoV-2 neutralizing antibody structures inform therapeutic strategies

item.title: Don’t dismiss carbon credits that aim to avoid future emissions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00972-2

Don’t dismiss carbon credits that aim to avoid future emissions
item.dc:title: Don’t dismiss carbon credits that aim to avoid future emissions
item.dc:creator: Edward Mitchard
Peter Ellis
Susan Cook Patton
Roselyn Fosuah Adjei

item.title: Right- or left-handed? Protein in embryo cells might help decide
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00977-x

Gene that codes for structural protein could determine the dominant side of the human brain.
item.dc:title: Right- or left-handed? Protein in embryo cells might help decide
item.dc:creator: Sumeet Kulkarni

item.title: Why hand-operated front brakes were set to be the future of motoring
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00918-8

The complexity of fitting brakes to all four wheels of a car and the simplicity of John Maynard Smith’s ecological models, in the weekly dip into Nature’s archive.
item.dc:title: Why hand-operated front brakes were set to be the future of motoring

item.title: Adopt universal standards for study adaptation to boost health, education and social-science research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00970-4

Adopt universal standards for study adaptation to boost health, education and social-science research
item.dc:title: Adopt universal standards for study adaptation to boost health, education and social-science research
item.dc:creator: Dragos Iliescu
Samuel Greiff

item.title: How can we make PhD training fit for the modern world? Broaden its philosophical foundations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00969-x

How can we make PhD training fit for the modern world? Broaden its philosophical foundations
item.dc:title: How can we make PhD training fit for the modern world? Broaden its philosophical foundations
item.dc:creator: Ganesh Alagarasan

item.title: Allow researchers with caring responsibilities ‘promotion pauses’ to make research more equitable
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00971-3

Allow researchers with caring responsibilities ‘promotion pauses’ to make research more equitable
item.dc:title: Allow researchers with caring responsibilities ‘promotion pauses’ to make research more equitable
item.dc:creator: Daniel H. Lowenstein

item.title: Long COVID still has no cure — so these patients are turning to research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00901-3

With key long COVID trials yet to yield results, people with the condition are trying to change how clinical trials are done.
item.dc:title: Long COVID still has no cure — so these patients are turning to research
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank

item.title: Impact factors are outdated, but new research assessments still fail scientists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00899-8

A move away from narrow assessment metrics such as publication records is welcome. Now planning and consultation is needed to make sure that replacements work better.
item.dc:title: Impact factors are outdated, but new research assessments still fail scientists
item.dc:creator: Kelly Cobey

item.title: ‘Maybe I was never meant to be in science’: how imposter syndrome seizes scientist mothers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00953-5

Brazilian biologist Fernanda Staniscuaski saw career opportunities diminish after returning from parental leave, prompting her to take action.
item.dc:title: ‘Maybe I was never meant to be in science’: how imposter syndrome seizes scientist mothers
item.dc:creator: Julie Gould

item.title: A 2023 hurricane caught Mexico off guard: we must work together to prepare better
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00904-0

Hurricane Otis yields lessons for researchers and policymakers on how to reduce risks in the face of inequality.
item.dc:title: A 2023 hurricane caught Mexico off guard: we must work together to prepare better
item.dc:creator: Gian C. Delgado-Ramos
Simone Lucatello
Debora Ley
Antonina Ivanova
Ma de Lourdes Romo-Aguilar
Cecilia Conde
Miguel Imaz-Lamadrid

item.title: ‘Mini liver’ will grow in person’s own lymph node in bold new trial
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00975-z

Biotechnology firm LyGenesis has injected donor cells into a person with liver failure for the first time.
item.dc:title: ‘Mini liver’ will grow in person’s own lymph node in bold new trial
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Africa’s postdoc workforce is on the rise — but at what cost?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00980-2

Will a growth in postdoctoral positions across Africa cause bottlenecks, replicating the career-progression challenges faced by scientists elsewhere?
item.dc:title: Africa’s postdoc workforce is on the rise — but at what cost?
item.dc:creator: Linda Nordling

item.title: Daily briefing: Patients lead the way on long COVID
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00985-x

People with long COVID played a crucial role in advising, designing and even funding basic and clinical research into the condition. Plus, long-term memories are formed by damaging DNA and South Korea will join Horizon Europe.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Patients lead the way on long COVID
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Cosmologist Claudia de Rham on falling for gravity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00903-1

The aspiring astronaut turned theoretical physicist talks travelling, the accelerating expansion of the Universe, thinking beyond three dimensions and detecting gravitational waves.
item.dc:title: Cosmologist Claudia de Rham on falling for gravity
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Gut bacteria break down cholesterol — hinting at probiotic treatments
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00955-3

Species in the human microbiome have enzymes that can metabolize a potentially dangerous lipid.
item.dc:title: Gut bacteria break down cholesterol — hinting at probiotic treatments
item.dc:creator: Julian Nowogrodzki

item.title: Is IVF at risk in the US? Scientists fear for the fertility treatment’s future
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00830-1

An Alabama court ruling that human embryos outside the uterus should be regarded as children has raised concerns among doctors and scientists.
item.dc:title: Is IVF at risk in the US? Scientists fear for the fertility treatment’s future
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07323-1

Complexity of avian evolution revealed by family-level genomes
item.dc:title: Complexity of avian evolution revealed by family-level genomes

item.title: Green space near home has an antidepressant effect
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00968-y

People who had the most vegetation near their residences were the least likely to report depression and anxiety.
item.dc:title: Green space near home has an antidepressant effect

item.title: How I use tide gauges to develop geospatial maps
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00908-w

Geographer Muh Aris Marfai collects reference data for Indonesia’s coastal areas to prepare for the impacts of climate change.
item.dc:title: How I use tide gauges to develop geospatial maps
item.dc:creator: Nikki Forrester

item.title: How scientists are making the most of Reddit
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00906-y

As X wanes, researchers are turning to Reddit for insights and data, and to better connect with the public.
item.dc:title: How scientists are making the most of Reddit
item.dc:creator: Hannah Docter-Loeb

item.title: How synthetic biologists are building better biofactories
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00907-x

Artificial electron donors and acceptors expand researchers’ metabolic engineering options — if only cells would cooperate.
item.dc:title: How synthetic biologists are building better biofactories
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: The great rewiring: is social media really behind an epidemic of teenage mental illness?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00902-2

The evidence is equivocal on whether screen time is to blame for rising levels of teen depression and anxiety — and rising hysteria could distract us from tackling the real causes.
item.dc:title: The great rewiring: is social media really behind an epidemic of teenage mental illness?
item.dc:creator: Candice L. Odgers

item.title: Copper-catalyzed dehydrogenation or lactonization of C(sp<sup>3</sup>)−H bonds
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07341-z

Copper-catalyzed dehydrogenation or lactonization of C(sp3)−H bonds
item.dc:title: Copper-catalyzed dehydrogenation or lactonization of C(sp<sup>3</sup>)−H bonds
item.dc:creator: Shupeng Zhou
Zi-Jun Zhang
Jin-Quan Yu

item.title: Scientists made a six-legged mouse embryo — here’s why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00943-7

A rodent with two extra limbs instead of genitals shows the crucial role of a gene pathway in determining the fate of a primordial structure.
item.dc:title: Scientists made a six-legged mouse embryo — here’s why
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: How a spreadsheet helped me to land my dream job
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00950-8

A shared spreadsheet, passed from generation to generation, helps graduate students in management navigate the academic job market. Whatever your field of study, you can make one, too.
item.dc:title: How a spreadsheet helped me to land my dream job
item.dc:creator: Silvia Sanasi

item.title: Daily briefing: Climate change is slowing Earth’s rotation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00979-9

Melting ice caps are slowing the rotation of the Earth and could delay the next leap second by three years. Plus, why journal editors are resigning en masse and how to make an old immune system young again.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Climate change is slowing Earth’s rotation
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: The corpse of an exploded star and more — March’s best science images
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00941-9

The month’s sharpest science shots, selected by Nature’s photo team.
item.dc:title: The corpse of an exploded star and more — March’s best science images
item.dc:creator: Emma Stoye

item.title: Sam Bankman-Fried sentencing: crypto-funded researchers grapple with FTX collapse
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00960-6

Organizations who received funds from FTX face pressure to return the money at significant operational cost.
item.dc:title: Sam Bankman-Fried sentencing: crypto-funded researchers grapple with FTX collapse
item.dc:creator: Jonathan O'Callaghan

item.title: This super-Earth is the first planet confirmed to have a permanent dark side
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00414-z

Convincing evidence of 1:1 tidal locking has been absent until a new analysis of the exoplanet LHS 3844b.
item.dc:title: This super-Earth is the first planet confirmed to have a permanent dark side
item.dc:creator: Joseph Howlett

item.title: Overcoming low vision to prove my abilities under pressure
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00957-1

A genetic eye condition pushed biochemist Kamini Govender to develop coping strategies that serve her well in the lab and help her to avoid burnout.
item.dc:title: Overcoming low vision to prove my abilities under pressure
item.dc:creator: Lesley Evans Ogden

item.title: How papers with doctored images can affect scientific reviews
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00875-2

Scientists compiling a review scan more than 1,000 papers and find troubling images in nearly 20%.
item.dc:title: How papers with doctored images can affect scientific reviews
item.dc:creator: Sumeet Kulkarni

item.title: Tweeting your research paper boosts engagement but not citations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00922-y

Analysis of a random selection of papers shared on social media showed no causative link between posting and citations.
item.dc:title: Tweeting your research paper boosts engagement but not citations
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: Video: Cancer-busting vaccines
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00842-x

Treatments that could train the immune system to identify and destroy cancer cells are on the way.
item.dc:title: Video: Cancer-busting vaccines

item.title: Cancer-vaccine trials give reasons for optimism
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00840-z

Therapeutic vaccines could provide a transformative shot in the arm for cancer treatment.
item.dc:title: Cancer-vaccine trials give reasons for optimism
item.dc:creator: Liam Drew

item.title: No sweat: Moisture-wicking device keeps wearable-tech dry
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00945-5

Breathable patch could allow for comfortable and multifunctional wearable electronics.
item.dc:title: No sweat: Moisture-wicking device keeps wearable-tech dry
item.dc:creator: Dan Fox

item.title: A global timekeeping problem postponed by global warming
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07170-0

Increased melting of ice in Greenland and Antarctica, measured by satellite gravity, has decreased the angular velocity of Earth more rapidly than before and has already affected global timekeeping.
item.dc:title: A global timekeeping problem postponed by global warming
item.dc:creator: Duncan Carr Agnew

item.title: CGRP sensory neurons promote tissue healing via neutrophils and macrophages
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07237-y

Experiments in mouse models show that NaV1.8+ nociceptors innervate sites of injury and provide wound repair signals to immune cells by releasing calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP).
item.dc:title: CGRP sensory neurons promote tissue healing via neutrophils and macrophages
item.dc:creator: Yen-Zhen Lu
Bhavana Nayer
Shailendra Kumar Singh
Yasmin K. Alshoubaki
Elle Yuan
Anthony J. Park
Kenta Maruyama
Shizuo Akira
Mikaël M. Martino

item.title: Formation of memory assemblies through the DNA-sensing TLR9 pathway
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07220-7

Learning results in persistent double-stranded DNA breaks, nuclear rupture and release of DNA fragments and histones within hippocampal CA1 neurons that, following TLR9-mediated DNA damage repair, results in their recruitment to memory circuits.
item.dc:title: Formation of memory assemblies through the DNA-sensing TLR9 pathway

item.title: The HEAT repeat protein HPO-27 is a lysosome fission factor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07249-8

The conserved HEAT repeat protein HPO-27 is identified as a lysosome scission factor in Caenorhabditis elegans, and the human homologue MROH1 also serves the same function to maintain lysosomal homeostasis.
item.dc:title: The HEAT repeat protein HPO-27 is a lysosome fission factor

item.title: Five million years of Antarctic Circumpolar Current strength variability
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07143-3

The strength of the Antarctic Circumpolar Current, as traced in sediment cores from the Pacific Southern Ocean, shows no linear long-term trend over the past 5.3 Myr; instead, the strongest flow occurs consistently in warmer-than-present intervals.
item.dc:title: Five million years of Antarctic Circumpolar Current strength variability

item.title: Optomechanical realization of the bosonic Kitaev chain
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07174-w

We report the experimental realization of a bosonic Kitaev chain in a nano-optomechanical network.

item.title: TRBC1-targeting antibody–drug conjugates for the treatment of T cell cancers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07233-2

Anti-TRBC1 antibody–drug conjugates may offer a more potent T cell cancer therapy by bypassing the fratricide that may be limiting the efficacy of anti-TRBC1 CAR T cells in the clinical trial for patients with T cell cancers.
item.dc:title: TRBC1-targeting antibody–drug conjugates for the treatment of T cell cancers

item.title: Depleting myeloid-biased haematopoietic stem cells rejuvenates aged immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07238-x

Antibody-mediated depletion of myeloid-biased haematopoietic stem cells in aged mice restores characteristic features of a more youthful immune system.
item.dc:title: Depleting myeloid-biased haematopoietic stem cells rejuvenates aged immunity
